Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Design and Implementation of New Wafer-Scale Millimeter-Wave Massive-MIMO Transceivers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project studies the implementation of the world?s first wafer-scale 100+ element massive MIMO transceiver operating at millimeter-wave frequency. An essential attribute of this system is the resource sharing of transceiver chains, leading to great saving of area. The proposed system is capable of accommodating any multi-antenna scheme, including spatial multiplexing, spatial diversity (including orthogonal space time block codes, maximal-ratio combining, and beamforming). This will result in significant improvement of performance and reduction of power consumption.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that it transforms the landscape of the broadband multi user wireless access across the globe and helps the U.S. wireless sector to be the leader of the world. The wafer-scale massive MIMO base stations will have tremendous impact on the emerging multi-function multi-antenna wireless communications by exploring theories and developing circuits and systems. The telecommunications sector is changing at warp speed, driven by technological innovation that results in new equipment and services. This STTR project will precisely contribute to this innovation in the United States by providing a foresight for the future direction of research and development in wireless communications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thanks to hyper connectivity and an explosion in new mobile devices and apps, we are at the verge of an astounding increase in the mobile traffic. The traffic is expected to increase by orders of magnitude in the near future. Although a huge challenge, this could be a unique opportunity for the wireless and semiconductor industries to benefit from its tremendous economical benefits. Small Cells, Massive MIMO, and MU-MIMO are among the most promising solutions to substantially boost the performance and speed of wireless networks. Moreover, mm-Wave frequencies are considered to be a very strong candidate because of very large bandwidth, attenuation profile, and very compact RF antennas.

During the course of this project we did a comprehensive research and study of communications system, standards, and network aspects of this technology. We did performance analysis and simulations of a Massive MIMO system. The idea was to quantify the achievable rates for a massive MIMO compared to a conventional MU-MIMO system and point-to-point MIMO systems. In addition, we designed an integrated circuit operating at mm-Wave frequencies to study the feasibility of an innovative code-multiplexing technique to substantially reduce the complexity of the RF transceiver.

In conventional MIMO systems, each antenna element has a dedicated  RF/IF/Base-band chain. This architecture leads to significant power dissipation and prohibitive chip area, making the Massive MIMO implementation impractical. Another significant drawback with this architecture is the need for sophisticated power-hungry LO distributions to deliver the LO signals to each TRX chain. These issues all scale up in their enormity and difficulty in the context of massive MIMO systems, in which 100+ transceivers are ultimately employed.

To overcome these challenges, we focused on an innovative method known as code multiplexed path sharing. The fundamental idea of path sharing is based on using orthogonal codes in baseband and RF sections of the TRX. For example in Tx, using orthogonal codes like Walsh code, information in the 8 baseband paths is code modulated by multiplying the code with baseband data and then all 8 orthogonal signals are summed into one shared signal. As a consequence, only one DAC, one filter and one up-converter and post-filter are needed for each 8-element cluster. Therefore, significant power saving is attained. 

We completed schematic and physical design of the building blocks of a mm-Wave Massive MIMO receiver composed of an 8-element path sharing Rx cluster. The technology of choice was SiGe BiCOMS process. The circuits are designed to operate at 60+GHz because of the growing interest in this band for the next generation of mobile networks and also taking a shot at pushing the limits of the silicon technology and mm-Wave design.

This work was the result of our collective efforts at Cepand, Inc. and Nanoscale Communication IC Lab of University of California, Irvine, during phase-I of our NSF STTR grant in 2014. Both teams dedicated tremendous efforts to innovate and push the boundaries of this complex technology.
